preset.headline: Embark on Epic Adventures Beyond Earth

preset.lead: Read more about Mars, Venus, and Jupiter.

entries.headline: Mars
entries.description: Mars has become a favorite subject of experts and enthusiasts everywhere. It's not hard to see why – the dense rock formations, captured asteroids, and stunning color all make for a breathtakingly different world. However, a few key facts show us that Mars isn't actually that different from our own.

entries.headline: Venus
entries.description:
In astrology, Venus is thought to represent love. However, the sheer difficulty of surviving on Venus means that it might be more accurate to say it represents tough love.
It's a well-known fact that humans wouldn't exactly thrive on the other planets in our solar system. However, Venus is one of the tougher options.

entries.headline: Jupiter
entries.description:
Jupiter is a gas giant unlike any other. Its giant size, multiple moons, and high speeds set it apart as a truly incredible planet.
Jupiter's size is undeniably impressive. However, it isn't just confined to the planet itself. It also puts things into perspective elsewhere: for as large as Jupiter is, you could easily fit it in between Earth and our Moon! Aren't cosmic distances wild?

preset.headline: Planet Facts

preset.lead: Space is the area beyond the upper limits of Earth’s atmosphere. Space is a vacuum, meaning it contains almost nothing, but it is not completely empty.

cards.text: Space does not begin at a specific altitude above the Earth, but the Kármán line at 100 km is a commonly used definition.
cards.label: Space

cards.text: Every star you see in the night sky is bigger and brighter than our sun. You can't see millions of stars on a dark night.
cards.label: Stars

cards.text: The International Space Station is the largest ever crewed object in space.
cards.label: ISS

cards.text: Comets are leftovers from the creation of our solar system about 4.5 billion years ago – they consist of sand, ice and carbon dioxide.
cards.label: Comets

cards.text: The hottest planet in the solar system is Venus. This scorching planet has an average surface temperature of about 232 °F (450 °C)
cards.label: The hottest planet

cards.text: The word astronaut comes from the Greek words for “star” and “sailor.” Not all astronauts are called astronauts...
cards.label: Astronaut

preset.headline: We don't know what we don't know.

presets.name: What do astronauts do for fun?

content.text: Astronauts typically have about 4-5 hours of free time per work day, as well as 2.5 hours of time to exercise. So, what do they do to avoid boredom?
Staring out the window is unsurprisingly a common pastime. Astronauts even get to experience a sunrise or sunset every 45 minutes while orbiting Earth.
When you are bunked this closely with your team, inevitably some time is spent hanging out with each other.
Astronauts commonly contact family and friends from their computers. They can call, email, or even video chat!
Astronauts have hobbies like the rest of us, so you might also catch them reading a book, watching DVDs, taking photographs of the incredible views, or even playing an musical instrument.

preset.headline: What do astronauts do for fun?

content.text: There are currently two Space Stations orbiting the Earth, the International Space Station (ISS) and China's Tiangong Space Station (TSS).
There are three rovers on Mars including the Curiosity, Perseverance, and Zhurong.
Nearly 5,000 active artificial satellites are orbiting the Earth.
Over 40 space telescopes of all different types are orbiting the earth.
Many other unmanned space missions are actively occurring.
